III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff responsibilities
Title
1

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The youth was taken to the hospital by a foster care case
manager. The youth was ready for discharge, but the residential
facility is refusing to take the youth back indicating that they were
unaware of his mental health and behaviors. The foster care
agency is not providing an alternative placement or picking the
youth up.
Investigation It was alleged this child placing agency refused to take
responsibility for the discharge of Youth A from the hospital.
Interviews:
I interviewed the CCI consultant for the residential facility where
Youth A was placed. The residential facility refused to accept
Youth A back following Youth A's hospitalization due to Youth A's
behaviors. A separate special investigation will be completed
associated with the actions of the residential facility.
I interviewed Complainant by telephone on 6/5/2024.
Complainant reported Youth A was placed at the hospital on
5/28/2024 and discharged on 6/4/2024. Complainant reported
Youth A was picked up upon discharge by Bethany Christian
Services (BCS) staff and placed with a relative of Youth A.
I interviewed Chief Administrator by telephone on 6/5/2024.
Chief Administrator stated the residential facility staff did not
transport Youth A to the hospital. Chief Administrator stated the
residential facility had the police transport Youth A to the hospital
and a Bethany Christian Services (BCS) worker followed them to
the hospital and stayed with Youth A for a little while. Chief
Administrator stated the agency does not have the authority to
place youth in a residential facility. That has to be authorized by
Western Michigan Partnership for Children (WMPC). Chief
Administrator stated the residential facility was refusing to take
Youth A back following Youth A's hospitalization. Chief
Administrator stated the agency continued to communicate with
2

the residential facility and hospital to facilitate the return of Youth
A or an alternative placement for Youth A. Chief Administrator
stated BCS staff continued to have contact with Youth A and the
hospital during Youth A's hospitalization while attempting to
facilitate an alternative placement. Chief Administrator provided
documentation consistent with this description of the activities by
BCS.
Documents Reviewed:
A summary of the documents submitted by Chief Administrator
related to BCS activities associated with this complaint is as
follows:
• 5/29/2024- BCS initiated statewide placement efforts
involving MDHHS offices and private child placing
agencies.
• 5/30/2024 - BCS staff contact/communication with the
mother of Youth A and conduct safety planning with Youth
A at the hospital.
• 5/31/2024 - Meeting between BCS and the residential
facility where Youth A was placed.
• 5/31/2024 - BCS contact with WMPC for guidance
regarding facilitating alternative placements for Youth A.
BCS again conducted a statewide placement search.
• 5/31/2024 - BCS staff contact with Youth A in which Youth
A reported thoughts of self-harm.
• 6/1/2024 - 2 social work contacts between BCS and
hospital staff.
• 6/2/2024 - Face to Face contact between BCS staff and
Youth A at the hospital.
• 6/3/2024 - BCS staff assessed/approved a relative of Youth
A for placement and updated the hospital regarding a
placement search.
• 6/4/2024 - Youth A discharged from the hospital and placed
with a relative by BCS.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance with CPA Rule 400.12207-3-a.
When the residential facility refused to take Youth A back
following his hospitalization, the agency responded by monitoring
Youth A's hospitalization and worked to facilitate an alternative
placement for Youth A. The agency did subsequently develop
and implement an alternative placement for Youth A with a relative
of Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
